profileText: A Representative from New York; born in New York City on June 16, 1786; was graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, N.H.; studied law; was admitted to the bar and practiced; settled in Saratoga County, N.Y.; elected as a Whig to the Twenty-sixth Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Anson Brown; took his seat on December 7, 1840, and served until March 3, 1841; resumed the practice of law; trustee of the village of Waterford, Saratoga County, in 1841; died at Saratoga Springs, N.Y., December 6, 1856; interment in Greenridge Cemetery.

note.content: Elected to fill vacancy caused by death of Anson Brown, and took his seat December 7, 1840.

researchRecord.name: 1840, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Augustus Pickering to Nicholas Doe written on December 20, 1840. In the letter, Pickering describing his activities since moving from New York to St. Joseph, Mich., in 1837, including an extended account of being caught in ice in the Straits of Mackinac and having to walk from Mackinaw City to Saginaw in winter and a briefer account of running aground the following year at Michigan City, Ind. Doe has added a brief letter of his own describing Congressional activities, addressed to his brother Joseph Doe, of South Burwick, Maine.
